column4: China suspends poultry imports from second U.S. plant over COVID-19, industry group says
column5: CHICAGO (Reuters) - China has suspended imports from an OK Foods poultry plant in Fort Smith, Arkansas, because of coronavirus cases among workers, the USA Poultry & Egg Export Council said on Tuesday.
column6: China, the world’s top meat importer, has blocked products from some plants in foreign countries as part of an all-out effort to control the spread of COVID-19.
column7: The OK Foods plant is the second U.S. poultry facility to be blocked because of an outbreak among employees, after Beijing suspended imports from a Tyson Foods Inc TSN.N plant in June.
column8: “We don’t think that either one of these two are justified, especially considering the fact that the virus cannot be transmitted in poultry meat,” said Jim Sumner, president of the USA Poultry & Egg Export Council.
column9: Chinese customs authority GACC suspended imports from the OK Foods facility, he said.
column10: OK Foods, owned by Mexico's Industrias Bachoco BACHOCOB.MX, did not immediately respond to requests for comment.
column11: The Arkansas plant became ineligible to ship products to China on Sept. 13, according to the U.S. Department of Agriculture.
column12: The Sept. 13 suspension was included on a list of recent changes to approved meat imports published on Sept. 15 on the website of China’s General Administration of Customs.
column13: Since the start of the pandemic, 234 plant workers had tested positive for COVID-19 as of Aug. 31, the Arkansas Department of Health said. The facility no longer has more than five active cases, according to the department, which publishes outbreak data on its website.

column4: China bans poultry from second U.S. plant over COVID-19, industry group says
column5: CHICAGO, Sept 15 (Reuters) - China has blocked imports from an OK Foods poultry plant in Fort Smith, Arkansas, because of coronavirus cases among workers, the president of the USA Poultry & Egg Export Council said on Tuesday.
column6: The plant is the second U.S. poultry facility to be blocked because of an outbreak, after Beijing suspended imports from a Tyson Foods Inc plant in June.
